Posted By: SpyCrab (1/24/2011 4:07:12 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Having just built a deck around this card, I'm very, very surprised it's still legal – I'm of the opinion that it should be banned across the board but restricted in Vintage, simply because it's one of those cards that has so much going for it for so little mana that there's almost no reason for a deck running black *not* to use it. 2 CMC card advantage – compared to the baseline established with [Divination](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Divination) and [Mind Rot](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mind Rot) – is more powerful than Wizards seems to be comfortable with; adding on to that the enormous number of ways your opponent may be screwed after those two random discards just makes this unbelievable.  
  
Never really having played a dedicated black discard deck before, and not having played at all in years, I'd forgotten how firmly this card can lock down a game. As if a card advantage for 2 wasn't enough, your opponent may very well have discarded their only two lands, or their only two non-lands, or one of their critical co... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Posted By: ThatGuyYouHate (12/31/2010 2:35:20 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Discard in general is ineffective in Vintage because there are so many "draw 7 cards" in the format and cards in graveyard could be considered as resources more often than not. Chance is they already played everything on their first or second turn and waiting for the draw 7 card spell ([wheel of fortune](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=wheel of fortune) or [timetwister](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=timetwister)), which is easily done by top decking [brainstorm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=brainstorm)/[ancestral recall](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=ancestral recall)/[ponder](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=ponder)/[merchant scroll](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=merchant scroll)/[mystical tutor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=mystical tutor).
  
   
But yes, this card is so unfair in legacy that it deserve a ban that few would complain about it.
posts.html:
Discard in general is ineffective in Vintage because there are so many "draw 7 cards" in the format and cards in graveyard could be considered as resources more often than not. Chance is they already played everything on their first or second turn and waiting for the draw 7 card spell (wheel of fortune or timetwister), which is easily done by top decking brainstorm/ancestral recall/ponder/merchant scroll/mystical tutor.

But yes, this card is so unfair in legacy that it deserve a ban that few would complain about it.

Posted By: blindthrall (12/24/2009 7:10:10 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@non1337, you're comparing a single mechanic of the game to the entire range of mechanics. Yes, discard on it's own might be ineffective in Vintage... but someone isn't only going to be packing discard spells in his deck. Combined with counter spells, discard can break early combos... the other cards should make sure the opponent doesn't draw 7.  
  
Saying a discard spell is ineffective in Vintage is like saying a mana acceleration in Vintage is ineffective because your spells will be countered anyway, or that tutoring is stupid in Vintage because the card you fetch might get discarded.
posts.html:
@non1337, you're comparing a single mechanic of the game to the entire range of mechanics. Yes, discard on it's own might be ineffective in Vintage... but someone isn't only going to be packing discard spells in his deck. Combined with counter spells, discard can break early combos... the other cards should make sure the opponent doesn't draw 7.

Saying a discard spell is ineffective in Vintage is like saying a mana acceleration in Vintage is ineffective because your spells will be countered anyway, or that tutoring is stupid in Vintage because the card you fetch might get discarded.

Posted By: Kragash (12/9/2011 3:02:51 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
A truly powerful card, but it certainly has its limitations. Early game though, that doesn't really matter, since the limitations are ignored. First, it can end up discarding land. This is probably a good thing. Second, it might discard something you don't want it to. That's alright too, because if you're playing this on turn 2, it's likely they kept their hand for a reason. It's going to hit at least one card they wanted more often than not.  
  
Given those factors, it's tremendously more powerful than [Distress](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Distress), as twice as many cards are discarded for the same cost, and it can hit lands.
posts.html:

Given those factors, it's tremendously more powerful than Distress, as twice as many cards are discarded for the same cost, and it can hit lands.
